Photo: Greg Morago Scenes from Southern Smoke. Image 38 of 38 Southern Smoke culinary blowout scores big 1 / 38 Back to Gallery When the smoke cleared, Underbelly chef Chris Shepherd was proud, grateful and astonished.
He hoped that the Southern Smoke fundraiser he organized to benefit the National Multiple Sclerosis Society on Oct. 11 would raise $100,000. At the end of the day the check was $183,989. Standing on a stage at the barbecue playground created between Underbelly, the Hay Merchant and Blacksmith restaurants, Shepherd thanked everyone involved and made a pledge: "Just so you know, this is going to be an annual event."
About 1,000 people attended the event that brought three of the country's best smoked meats and Southern foods practitioners to Houston: Aaron Franklin (famed Austin pitmaster at Franklin Barbecue , who this year won the James Beard Award for Best Chef: Southwest); Sean Brock (of Husk and McCrady's in Charleston, S.C., and a two-time James Beard Award winner); and Rodney Scott (the whole-hog pitmaster who has made Scott's Bar-B-Que in Hemingway, S.C., one of the country's most beloved smoked meat meccas). The event also marks the debut of HOUBBQ Collective, a group of local chefs, including Shepherd, Seth Siegel-Gardner and Terrence Gallivan of the Pass & Provisions , Ryan Pera of Coltivare and Justin Yu of Oxheart .
Shepherd organized the smoky extravaganza after learning that his friend, Antonio Gianola, one of the city's top wine experts, had been diagnosed with MS.
"When I told Chris he said, let's not do a dinner, let's do a party," Gianola recalled.
And what a party. The sold-out event (tickets were $200 general admission; $300 VIP) featured unlimited tastings, wine (Underbelly sommelier Matthew Pridgen and Camerata wine director David Keck oversaw the donations), beer from Saint Arnold's and Karbach, and live music from Folk Family Revival. Silent auction items helped push the event over its goal.
Gianola said he was glad he confided in Shepherd about his medical condition. "I thought the only way to make a difference is to tell people and show that you can still be successful in your field and have a life," Gianola said. He called the event "overwhelming and wonderful."
For barbecue fans it was that, indeed. The HOUBBQ Collective brought its A-game. Pera served a "tongue and cheek" dog (smoked tongue and cheek bratwurst) with Texas chow-chow and smoked cheddar cheese. Yu served smoked sticky rice with crispy chicken skin. And Gallivan and Siegel-Gardner served smoked Peking duck on a steamed bun with hoisin sauce and sweet and sour pickles.
The three visiting chefs said they were honored to be part of the event.
Scott, second-generation owner of Scott's Bar-B-Que in Hemingway, S.C., is known for whole hog cooking over wood-burning pits. He brought that technique to the event where who big hogs (162 pounds, 148 pounds) fed Southern Smoke attendees. The splayed pigs were first cooked skin-side down for 12 hours then flipped and mopped with Carolina-style vinegar and pepper sauce. The meat bubbled in its own juices on the pits, which Southern Goods pitmaster Patrick Feges helped build.
Before Southern Smoke Scott said he'd never been to Houston except to change planes. But he was given a royal tour by Shepherd, hitting Chinatown, Coltivare, and the Pass & Provisions. He also ate banh mi and kolaches.
"Texas gave me a lot of love since I've been here. It's the true South," he said. "It's a whole new world out here. It's very Southern and very metropolitan at the same time."
Brock of Charleston also had never been to Houston before coming out for Southern Smoke. He said he immediately felt a great vibe from the city. "There's a sense of pride people have here and it's contagious," he said, adding that events like Southern Smoke are what make the city tick. "This is what makes communities amazing. You create a singular thing in your community that you're proud of and it's amazing."
Brock said he spent hours talking to Franklin about Central Texas-style barbecue. "It's just a completely different way of thinking. But it reminds us of what makes barbecue amazing; it's such a regional, distinctive thing. We can all learn from each other."
Brock diverted from the smoked meat route by serving red snapper on a tomato and cucumber salad. The Snapper was cooked skin-on and swabbed with a butter sauce enriched with 'nduja (a spicy pork spread) and chopped lovage.
The pitmaster with the longest line for food belonged to Franklin. It was a chance for Houston to sample his style of smoked brisket without enduring the even longer lines at Franklin Barbecue in Austin.
Franklin doesn't often bring his pits out for barbecue events but he said that when Shepherd asked him to be part of the fundraiser he said, "What day? What time? I'll be there."
Franklin, who served brisket on white bread with espresso barbecue sauce and dill pickle chips, praised the local barbecue scene. "I think it's awesome. It's about time for the next-level stuff," he said.
